awd_titl_txt: HRRBAA: Paleoanthropological Investigations of Early Pleistocene Hominin Dispersals
awd_abstract_narration:
Fossil evidence for hominins in Western Europe currently dates to as early as ~1.4 million years ago (Ma). The same time period in Eastern Europe remains understudied, even though it is likely to have been a route of hominin dispersal into the rest of Europe. This high-risk research project will undertake a paleontological and geological survey of the Olteþ River Valley, Romania, which is the location of the richest fossil site of mammalian fauna in Eastern Europe from this time period. The investigators will look for evidence of hominin occupation at a few known sites, search for additional sites, and collect data to understand the paleoenvironment of the region and confirm dates for the sites. As an area that served as a likely migration route, new discoveries would shed valuable information on the peopling of Western Europe. This project will encourage gender and ethnic diversity in science by providing research opportunities for undergraduate students at three universities that primarily educate first-generation college and minority students. It will also support early career female scientists, international collaborations among US and Romanian scientists, and community science outreach. 

Evidence suggests that fossil hominins successfully dispersed from Africa to Georgia and Indonesia by 1.85 Ma, but the earliest evidence in Europe is not until ~1.4 Ma. There are two possible explanations for this apparent late dispersal: 1) some barrier prohibited hominin dispersal into Europe, or 2) hominins were present there earlier than 1.4 Ma but paleontological investigations have not yet uncovered their presence. While sites from this time period in Western Europe have been intensively investigated, paleontological localities in Eastern Europe have not been as thoroughly explored. The Olteþ River Valley of Romania has yielded a series of fossil sites that may shed light on dispersal patterns into Europe during the early Pleistocene, and preliminary work suggests that this region has the potential to yield additional sites. This high-risk research project will undertake a paleontological and geological survey of the Olteþ River Valley to look for evidence of hominin occupation during the early Pleistocene, and conduct preliminary investigations of the area's paleoenvironment. By locating and analyzing data from fossil sites from the early Pleistocene of Romania, we can determine whether the fauna from these sites were similar to those found at other early Pleistocene hominin sites across Eurasia, or whether there were differences among these sites that were important for preventing hominin dispersals into Europe at this time. Critically, examination of fossils from these localities and identification of any potential stone tools and/or cut marked bones has the potential to establish the presence of hominins in this region during the early Pleistocene. If so, this would represent the earliest evidence of hominins in Europe west of Georgia.

por.por_cntn:
The timing and conditions of the earliest migrations of hominins (humans and our ancestors) into Europe are currently unclear. Although fossil evidence suggests that hominins were present on the eastern edge of Europe in Georgia and Southeast Asia by 1.85 million years ago (Ma), they seemingly did not reach Europe until closer to 1.4 Ma. One possible explanation for this temporal gap is that hominins were present in Europe prior to 1.4 Ma, but we have yet to uncover evidence of their presence. Although Western Europe has been intensively investigated, paleontological localities in Eastern Europe have not been as thoroughly explored. Understanding the environment of Eastern Europe during this time frame is critical, as this is the region through which hominins likely dispersed into the rest of Europe. The goal of this research is to bring together an international team of experts in paleoanthropology and geology to undertake continued surveys and excavations in the Oltet River Valley (ORV) of Romania, which are designed to document the presence and estimate the age of paleontological deposits in this region. By collecting and analyzing data from fossil sites from the early Pleistocene of Romania (between ~2 and 1.5 Ma), we can determine whether the fossil assemblages from these sites are similar to those found at contemporaneous hominin sites across Eurasia, or whether there were differences among these sites that were important for preventing hominin movements into Europe at this time. Critically, examination of fossils from these localities and identification of any stone tools and/or cut-marked bones has the potential to establish the presence of fossil hominins in this region during the early Pleistocene. If so, this would represent the earliest evidence of hominins in Europe west of Georgia.

In May/June 2017 we undertook a 3.5 week field season. Our crew included five American and Romanian principal investigators as well as three additional Romanian researchers and four US graduate students. This research focused on three activities: 1) extensive vehicular and pedestrian surveys of potential fossil localities throughout the Oltet River Valley, 2) excavations at known fossil localities, and 3) preparatory and curation work at the “Emil Racovita” Institute of Speleology in Bucharest.

During this field season, we examined a total of 56 potential localities across the ORV. Survey locations were identified via a combination of visual inspection during travel around the valley, satellite imagery, and discussion with Romanian locals. This survey identified one new site, Dealul Mamutului (“Mammoth Hill”), which contained a mammoth tusk and assorted other fossil remains. Survey efforts were also successful in re-identifying a site excavated in the 1960s, Fantana lui Mitilan. Excavation work uncovered additional fossil mammoth remains at the previously identified site of Rapa. We also undertook sediment coring with the goal of further characterizing the geology at this site, and we began excavation of several geological sections adjacent to the previously excavated site of Graunceanu, a site with one of the most extensive collections of fossils from the early Pleistocene of Eastern Europe. All fossils recovered during this field season were removed, cleaned, and returned to the Institute of Speleology in Bucharest for further analysis. Work at the Institute of Speleology focused on cleaning and curating fossil materials from the ORV. We further undertook a preliminary taphonomic analysis of the ORV fossil remains. Taphonomic analyses examine marks on the surface of fossils, which enables us to better understand how the fossils may have been modified around the time of death and after death. Damage to bone surfaces created by insects and/or roots/rhizomes was commonly observed on the ORV fossils, while other alterations were far more infrequent, including excavator/cleaning marks, carnivore tooth marks, trample marks, and possible cut-marks. There is little evidence of bone weathering or transport of the bones postmortem, and multiple specimens were excavated in articulation with other bones from the same individual. These findings suggest that fossil remains were quickly covered with sediment after their deposition. 

There are several broader impacts of this work. This research brings together an international team of researchers from the United States and Romania, which represents an invaluable interdisciplinary and international approach that strengthened international ties and allowed mentoring among peers. Further, two of the PIs are early-career female investigators in a field (paleoanthropology) that has historically been male-dominated. Critically, the inclusion of four US graduate students in this research provides important training to the next generation of researchers. Examples and data from this research have been used in a variety of public outreach events, including visits to and activities with K-12 students in Northwest Arkansas, southeast Ohio, and New York City, university open house events at the University of Arkansas and Ohio University, and a variety of other STEM education events.
